awd_titl_txt: RAPID:  Text Message-Based Infrastructure for Emergency Response
awd_abstract_narration:
The 7.0 Earthquake in Haiti has mobilized the entire world to support
the relief effort, especially through novel uses of the cyberspace.  
Even though the earthquake damaged much of the communication 
infrastructure in Haiti, Haiti's Internet connectivity is robust 
because most Haitian Internet Service Providers use satellite, rather
than the damaged undersea fiber optic cable link, to connect to the 
Internet. Consequently, relief workers, regular citizens, and 
non-governmental organizations (NGO's) have used Tweets extensively 
to spread and share information about the needs, events, and relief 
operations.  However, these tweets are not easily aggregated into 
meaningful topics for ease of delivery to people who critically need 
the information. 

The goal of this research project is to develop and 
deploy, in collaboration with an NGO coordination body (NetHope), 
a reusable text message-based infrastructure that classifies and 
aggregates multi-lingual tweets and text messages about Haiti 
relief operations by topics and regions so that they can be easily 
subscribed by NGO's, survivors in Haiti, and their friends and 
families. The research project leverages existing software 
developed for entity extraction and topic classification so that the 
system can be developed and deployed quickly to respond to the time 
critical needs at Haiti.  

The evaluation of the system includes
feedbacks from NetHope as well as quantitative metrics about the
usage and performance of the system.  The intellectual merit of the 
research is developing integrated engineering solution to automatic 
identification of topics and geo-location from short-messages 
utilizing contextual information, which lays important foundation 
for designing the next-generation information infrastructure for 
emergency response and disaster management. For further information
see the project web page: URL: http://www.emerse.ist.psu.edu
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Tweets and short text messages have been generated in large volume during extreme events such as the Haiti earthquake and the Fukishima nuclear disaster.  While many of these short text messages contain useful information for assessing damages and identifying needs of survivors, they are not well-organized to allow critical information to be easily aggregated so that they can be acted upon by relief workers in a timely and effective way.

Even though text documents such as scholarship publications and news articles have been successfully classified by computers, tweets and short text messages remain difficult for computers to classify automatically because they contain much less words.  To solve this problem, this RAPID project uses a novel method to classify short text messages about Haiti earthquake (collected by Ushahidi http://haiti.ushahidi.com) into categories meaningful for relief workers.  A key novelty of the method is that it clusters words based on the similarity of the frequency of their occurrences in different categories.  This method is shown to perform better than other existing methods. 

The second contribution of this RAPID research is the identification of organizational barriers for NGO’s to adopt microblogging as trustworthy information for disaster relief, and a proposed social-technical solution for addressing such barriers.  These results can contribute to policy changes that facilitate information sharing and coordination among NGO’s by better leveraging the information in tweets in short text messages.

The RAPID project also provided a unique interdisciplinary education and training experience for a diversified group of undergraduate students, graduate students, and post doc, working with six faculty mentors.

A cloud-based infrastructure for large-scale streamline processing of text messages during extreme events has been developed.  Further information and publications of RAPID project can be found at http://emerse.ist.psu.edu.  The web site also displays tweets streamed from several NGO’s and the results of classifying them in real-time using the novel tweet classification method mentioned above.   The software that implements this method for classifying tweets is publically available for download in SourceForge.net under the name “Abstraction-based short text classification”.
